subject: Re: [junit] Re: Overriding AssertEquals
msgSnippet: ... Yes: I just learned something about List.containsAll(). It doesn t work the way I would have expected it to work. I suppose my argument only works for a
messageBody:
Ben Sandee wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> >You're right. I missed this:
> >
> >...for any collections /of the same type/ (both Sets, both Lists or both
> >Maps).
> >
> >Implicit assumption. :)
> >
> >
>
> ooh! ooh!
>
> List collectionA = Arrays.asList(new String[] {"x", "y", "z", "x"}));
> List collectionB = Arrays.asList(new String[] {"x", "y", "z", "k"}));
>
> ??
>
> collectionB.containsAll(collectionA) == true
> collectionA.containsAll(collectionB) == false
>
> are we having fun yet?

Yes: I just learned something about List.containsAll(). It doesn't work
the way I would have expected it to work.

I suppose my argument only works for a Set (including the keys of a Map).

The question is whether I'll remember this when next I need it. :)
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
